Graphical abstract A cobalt and boron co-doped biconical microrod-structured catalyst is fabricated for nitrogen reduction reaction and oxygen evolution reaction. It exhibits a high-power density of 8.30 mW cm−2 and an excellent NH3 production capacity in the Zn-N2 system. Zn-N2 batteries, which are comprised of nitrogen reduction reaction (NRR) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER), represent an emerging technology for efficient ammonia production and simultaneous power generation. Nevertheless, the intrinsic limitations of NRR and OER currently preclude its advancement. In this paper, Co and B co-doped Lavoisier framework series materials (MIL) are synthesized. Rapid mass transfer is rendered feasible with B0.25-MIL-88-Fe4Co1 by the distinctive double cone microrods structure. The addition of soft acid metal node Co2+ and B with defective electronic structure modifies the electronic configuration of MIL-88-Fe. At the same time, doping causes defects in the metal-organic frameworks, expands effectively the pore size, and increases the specific surface area, thereby expediting the adsorption of N2 and the release of O2. The electrocatalysis results show that the dual-doping scheme increases the NH3 yield (127.27 μg−1 h−1 mg−1 cat) and Faraday efficiency (25.81%) while reducing the overpotential of OER (330 mV), achieving a power density of 8.30 mW cm−2 for Zn-N2 batteries. This discovery implements another avenue for the exploration of Zn-N2 battery materials and holds broader significance for advancing the field of energy storage and conversion. Keywords Nitrogen reduction reaction Oxygen evolution reaction Zn-N2 battery Dual doping MOF 1 Introduction As a significant chemical raw material, NH3 plays an indispensable role in the production of refrigerants, fertilizer, and fuels [1,2]. At present, the manufacturing of NH3 mainly relies on the extremely polluting, energy-intensive, and low-yield Haber-Bosch process [3,4]. Zn-N2 battery possesses several advantages, including high theoretical energy density, enhanced safety, and low cost. It has an extremely strong NH3 production capacity accompanied by energy output, which is why it has garnered substantial attention from numerous researchers [1,5,6]. Zn-N2 batteries system encompasses oxygen evolution reaction (OER) and nitrogen reduction reaction (NRR). OER reaction involves complex multi-electron transfer processes and slow charge transfer kinetics [7,8]. As for NRR reaction, due to the extremely high bond energy of the NN, N2 is difficult to be activated under normal temperature and pressure [3,9,10]. At the same time, there is a strongly competitive hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) in the aqueous environment [11,12]. Therefore, NRR process for NH3 synthesis which is based on normal temperature and pressure faces challenges of low NH3 production rate and Faraday efficiency. The crux to settling these constraints of Zn-N2 lies in the reasonable exploitation of an efficient bifunctional catalyst. Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are materials made up of the connection of organic ligands and inorganic metal ions to create a three-dimensional porous structure [13,14]. The enormous specific surface area, optimum dispersion of metal sites, regulable porosity, and abundant functionalization endow MOFs with broad applications prospects [15,16]. Among the various MOF materials, Fe-MOF has garnered significant attention due to its distinctive advantages [17,18]. Fe-MOF has satisfactory stability, allowing it to preserve a relatively constant structure and performance in complex situations [19]. At the same time, iron is low in toxicity and readily available, which reduces the cost of Fe-MOF manufacture [20]. Iron has diverse oxidation states, and the performance of Fe-MOFs can be modified by adjusting the oxidation state of iron in accordance with reaction requirements [21]. Most importantly, the Fe-MOF contains a significant number of high-energy-density unsaturated active sites [17]. The above features have propelled the widespread application of Fe-MOF in the field of catalysis. Low conductivity and stability are presently the pivotal factors restricting the extensive application of MOFs in the field of catalysis [22]. As of present time, although some derivative carbon materials can be obtained by pyrolysis, this process requires substantial energy and disrupts the internal orderliness of the MOFs structure [23,24]. The doping strategy treats the original drawbacks of MOFs while averting the emergence of new issues. It alters the metal ions and ligand structures to stimulate the redistribution of charge density, which modifies the unsatisfactory catalytic performance [25,26]. The addition of M2+ can help enlarge the pore channels of Fe-MOF, thereby expediting the adsorption of N2 and the release of O2 [26]. At the same time, mixed metal ions can also facilitate the migration of electrons between O and M, optimizing conductivity while encouraging the generation of reactive intermediates during the OER reaction [27,28]. The adsorption and activation of N2 are crucial for perfecting the performance of NRR [3]. Boron (B) is a prototypical electron-deficient configuration with vacant sp 2 orbitals that can bind with the lone pair of electrons of N2 to aid adsorption and cleavage of NN bond [29,30]. Moreover, the doping of B can trigger lattice flaws that elevate the amount of unsaturated active sites [22]. At present, there are relatively more studies on the single doped MOF. However, few researchers have conducted in-depth research on double-doped MOF materials, especially in terms of their application as bifunctional catalysts for Zn-N2 batteries. In this work, we constructed the metal and non-metal co-doped B0.25-MIL-88-Fe4Co1 material by a secondary solvothermal method as a bifunctional catalyst for Zn-N2 batteries. This material exhibits unique morphological features (double cone microrods), acting a positive role in expediting the transfer of ions and electrons in electrocatalysis [31,32]. In accordance with the soft acid-base theory [33], we select the metal cation (Co2+) with a low ionization potential that has analogous electronic structure to Fe3+ (3d 5). Co2+, as a soft acid metal node for electron donation, combines with the Fe3+, which has high ionization potential value to construct the bimetallic MOF at first. The electron transfer process is regulated by adjusting the proportion of metal nodes, thereby optimizing the conductivity and stability of MOF materials. Subsequently, through the solvothermal process again, B is doped and defect regions are formed on the surface of the MOFs, which enhance the active sites while motivating mass transfer. B0.25-MIL-88-Fe4Co1, which benefits from the previously listed factors, has impressive NRR/OER performance. The ammonia yield reaches 127.27 μg−1 h−1 mg−1 cat and the Faraday efficiency is 25.81%, exceeding most catalysts reported currently. Therefore, this material shows excellent potential as an electrode material for Zn-N2 batteries. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of MIL-88-FexCoy MIL-88-Fe preparation is displayed in the Supporting Information. On the premise of ensuring that the total amount of metals x + y = 2 mmol, cobalt-doped MIL-88-Fe x Co y is prepared by solvothermal method (x/y represents the molar ratio of FeCl3·H2O to CoCl2·H2O, where x/y is 6/1, 4/1, and 2/1). 2.2 Synthesis of Bz-MIL-88-Fe4Co1 As shown in Fig. 1 , the 300 mg MIL-88-Fe4Co1 was dispersed in a 20 mL solution, which was prepared by dissolving different moles of H3BO3 (0.125, 0.25, and 0.5 mol) into 20 mL H2O, then keeping the mixture in a Teflon-lined autoclave at 90 °C for 1 h. The solid was collected by centrifugation, successively washed with ultrapure water several times, and dried under vacuum at 60 °C overnight. The samples were labeled as B z -MIL-88-Fe4Co1 (the moles of H3BO3 are represented by z, where z is 0.125, 0.25, and 0.5). 2.3 Synthesis of B0.25-MIL-88-Fe B0.25-MIL-88-Fe was synthesized using similar method that was detailed for B0.25-MIL-88-Fe4Co1, except for changing MIL-88-Fe4Co1 to MIL-88-Fe. 2.4 Electrochemical measurements Electrochemical measurements were carried out utilizing CHI 618E workstation with a typical three-electrode system under room temperature in the H-type cell. The Ag/AgCl and graphite rod were employed as the reference and counter electrode, respectively. The preparation of working electrode details can be seen in the Supporting Information. All the potentials reported were converted into a reversible hydrogen electrode (vs. RHE) according to Nernst equation E (vs. RHE) = E (vs. Ag/AgCl) + 0.0591 × pH + 0.197 V. 2.4.1 Oxygen evolution reaction (OER) For OER tests, the initial step was to conduct cyclic voltammetry (CV) tests in 1 M KOH solution with O2 saturation at a scan rate of 2 mV s−1 from −0.5 to 1.4 V (vs. RHE). Subsequently, linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) tests were performed in the range of 1.0–2.2 V (vs. RHE) with the scan rate of 5 mV s−1 while maintaining a rotation speed of 1600 r min−1. 2.4.2 Nitrogen reduction reaction (NRR) In the NRR experiment, LSV was performed at a scan rate of 5 mV s−1 in 0.1 M HCl solution saturated with N2/Ar to evaluate the preferred potential range for NRR reaction. The cathode chamber was continuously purged with N2 for a 2-hour potentiostatic test. 2.5 Zn-N2 battery measurements The Neware Battery test instrument (CT-3008 W-5 V 30 mA-S4, Shenzhen Neware Instrument Company) was used to estimate Zn-N2 battery performance in a rechargeable H-cell device, in which Nafion 117 membrane effectively separates the anode and cathode, which were assembled by using the Zn plate as the anode and nickel foam with a loaded catalyst as cathode, respectively. Galvanostatic discharge charge experiment for 4 h (at 10 mA cm−2 both for 2-hour charge and 2-hour discharge) was conducted at a certain current density in an N2-saturated 1 M KOH or 0.1 M HCl solution. More experimental details can be found in the Supporting Information. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterizations of as-prepared electrocatalysts The phase compositions of MIL-88-Fe and MIL-88-Fe x Co y are characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD), as shown in Fig. 2 (a). The MIL-88-Fe exhibits three prominent diffraction peaks at 2θ angles of 9.18°, 9.94°, and 10.97°, corresponding to the crystal planes (002), (100), and (101), respectively, which aligns with previously reported results in the literature [34,35]. However, the ionic radius of Co2+ is slightly larger than that of Fe3+. Therefore, when Fe3+ is partially replaced by Co2+, the interplanar spacing will be increased, leading to the characteristic peak of MIL-88-Fe shifting towards a lower angle [36]. Notably, MIL-88-Fe x Co y and MIL-88-Fe display similar crystalline structures, indicating that the doping of Co does not alter the inherent topological structure of MIL-88-Fe. Fig. 2(b) displays the XRD patterns of B z -MIL-88-Fe4Co1 and B0.25-MIL-88-Fe. The intensity of the peaks decreases, and the diffraction peaks shift towards lower angles, which is attributed to the increase of boron doping. The above results signify that B doping leads to lattice distortions and gradually degrades ordering within the MOF material. The values of grain size and distortion rate for various samples are presented in Table S1. The morphology of MIL-88-Fe and series of doped samples was utilized scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM) to investigate. As shown in Fig. 2(c–f) and Figs. S1–S3, all the samples appeared as double-cone microrods, with the length and diameter being slightly enlarged with the Co, B doping (Table S2), substantiating the existence of lattice expansion. The insets in Fig. 2(c and d) are histograms corresponding to the lengths of samples. It can be observed that lengths of samples are in the range of 0.8 to 1.1 μm. These observed morphological changes are consistent with the results obtained from XRD patterns. Excess cobalt reacts with terephthalic acid (H2BDC) to form particles that cover the surface of the double-cone microrods, leading to an increase in their surface energy, thereby causing agglomeration ( Fig. S1c ). The unique structure of the double-cone microrods can enhance the contact area between the sample and the electrolyte, resulting in a rapid penetration of the electrolyte that facilitates the transport of ions and electrons [31]. At the same time, bilateral tips are more conducive to the accumulation of the electric field, which can enhance the kinetics of OER under alkaline conditions [32]. Furthermore, the elemental mapping and energy dispersive spectrometer (EDS) images of B0.25-MIL-88-Fe4Co1 have shown in Fig. 2(g and h). The five elements Fe, Co, C, O, and B show a uniform distribution, with the atom ratio of Fe to Co being approximately 4:1. It is evidenced that Co and B have been triumphantly doped into MIL-88-Fe based on the above results. The investigation of the catalyst structure through fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectrum has shown in Fig. 3 (a). At 1599 and 1392 cm−1, the existence of carboxylic acid structures has been proved due to the presence of asymmetric and symmetric stretching vibrations for CO [37]. The peak of 1070 cm−1 is the most commonly associated with stretching vibration of CO, while the stretching vibration mode of CH inside the benzene ring at the band of 750 cm−1 is observed [38]. FeO/CoO vibrational modes are represented by the peak at 550 cm−1 [39]. Moreover, the peak of B0.25-MIL-88-Fe4Co1 at 1700 cm−1 stands for the vibrations of BO2 −, verifying the successful doping of B [40]. Additionally, the catalyst structure could be deeply analyzed by Raman spectra performs (Fig. 3b). The peaks at 630 and 865 cm−1 correspond to external plane deformations of the CH bond, whereas the stretching vibrations of CC and CC bonds within the benzene ring are related to bands at 1138 and 1610 cm−1, respectively [41,42]. At peaks of 1445 and 1501 cm−1, the symmetric vibration of vs(OCO) and the asymmetric vibration of vas(OCO) appear [43]. Noticeably, contrasted to MIL-88-Fe and MIL-88-Fe4Co1, the peak intensity of the B-doped samples (B0.25-MIL-88-Fe and B0.25-MIL-88-Fe4Co1) notably declines, which correlates with structural defects [44]. The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) nitrogen sorption experiment is conducted to explore the effect of Co and B doping on the specific surface area and porous structure of MIL-88-Fe. The H3 hysteresis loop characteristics of the IV isothermal curves in Fig. 3(c) denote the presence of mesopores in B0.25-MIL-88-Fe4Co1 [45]. As observed from Fig. 3(d) and Table S3, the average pore diameter of MIL-88-Fe is increased from the original 16 to 22 nm for MIL-88-Fe4Co1 and B0.25-MIL-88-Fe4Co1, indicating that the addition of Co2+ can effectively enlarge pore diameter of MIL-88-Fe [26]. Besides, the specific surface area has been augmented because the B doping causes defects in the structure. The specific surface area (36.81 m2 g−1) of B0.25-MIL-88-Fe is approximately 2.3 times greater than that of MIL-88-Fe. With the addition of Co and B, B0.25-MIL-88-Fe4Co1 shows a remarkable increase in specific surface area (48.31 m2 g−1) and pore volume (0.26 cm3 g−1), which not only provides more active sites but also promotes nitrogen adsorption and mass transport processes involved in electrocatalysis. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was used to determine the elemental composition and valence states of samples. The XPS spectrum of B0.25-MIL-88-Fe4Co1 argues the existence of elements C, O, B, Fe, and Co (Fig. S4a), along with the corresponding atomic contents of these elements presented in Table S4, which matches the results obtained from EDS, indicating the effective synthesis of boron-doped bimetallic MOF. The CO, CO, and CC bonds demonstrated through Fig. S4(b) can be attributed to three sites with deconvolution of the C 1s peak at 288.8, 285.4, and 284.8 eV, respectively [46]. As illustrated in Fig. 3(e), The Fe 2p orbitals can be fitted into two satellite peak and two spin-orbit peaks (2p 1/2 and 2p 3/2), which are located at peak binding energies of 725.2 and 711.7 eV (Δ 13.5 eV = Fe 2p 1/2 − Fe 2p 3/2), confirming that the iron exists as Fe3+ in MIL-88-Fe [47]. It is noteworthy that for the MIL-88-Fe4Co1 doped with Co2+, the peaks of Fe 2p 1/2 (725.5 eV) and 2p 3/2 (711.9 eV) shifted towards higher binding energies by 0.3 and 0.2 eV, respectively. The emergence of this shift is conducive to enhancing the adsorption of nitrogen in NRR [48]; meanwhile electrons have transferred between Fe and Co, which can improve the performance of OER [8]. In addition, the binding energies of Fe 2p in B0.25-MIL-88-Fe4Co1 shift towards lower angles compared to MIL-88-Fe4Co1, and Fe peak in B0.25-MIL-88-Fe also exhibits similar shift in contrast to MIL-88-Fe, which is ascribed to lattice strain with the introduction of B [49]. The peak position of MIL-88-Fe4Co1 is observed at 783.0/798.3 eV and 781.5/796.7 eV, which corresponds to Co3+ and Co2+ [47,50], respectively (Fig. 3f). During the synthesis process, only cobalt in the +2 state was utilized. Thus, the emergence of Co3+ affirms that cobalt is smoothly doped and replaces the Fe position within MIL-88-Fe. The decrease in the peak area of Co 2p and the shift towards negative angles for B0.25-MIL-88-Fe4Co1 in contrast with MIL-88-Fe4Co1 are due to the secondary solvothermal process for doping B, resulting in the leaching of metal ions. As shown in Fig. 3(g), there are three convolution peaks of O 1s at 532.5, 531.7, and 530.2 eV, corresponding to MO, CO, and OH, respectively. Compared with MIL-88-Fe4Co1 and MIL-88-Fe, following the partial substitution of organic ligands by BO2 −, the enhancement of MO peak area and the positional shift for B0.25-MIL-88-Fe4Co1 and B0.25-MIL-88-Fe denote that the MOF structure had changed [49,51]. It can be seen from Fig. 3(h), the existence of BO is evidenced by the peak observed at 192.1 eV [52]. The comprehensive XPS results indicate that the double-doping alters the electronic structure of the catalyst and leads to a strong coupling effect among Fe, Co, and B. 3.2 Electrochemical performance toward OER LSV testing was waged in 1 M KOH to research the influence of ion doping on OER through assessing the overpotential values [53]. In Fig. 4 (a), the current density of MIL-88-Fe4Co1 exhibits a rapid increase with the rise in potential, reaching a minimum overpotential of 1.56 V at current density of 10 mA cm−2, which is superior to B0.25-MIL-88-Fe4Co1 (1.61 V), MIL-88-Fe (1.78 V), and B0.25-MIL-88-Fe (1.87 V). The performance amelioration of MIL-88-Fe4Co1 contrasted to MIL-88-Fe is ascribed to the introduction of Co, which motivates electron transfer. Simultaneously, it can be seen from Fig. S5 that doping Co facilitates the sample hydrophilicity and promotes the mass transfer process at the gas-solid-liquid interface [51]. The fundamental reason for the decline of OER performance after boric acid treatment of the sample is attributed to the leaching of metal ions, which results in a reduction of active sites. The Tafel slope of MIL-88-Fe4Co1 is 33.67 mV dec−1, which is conspicuously lower than that of B0.25-MIL-88-Fe4Co1 (52.85 mV dec−1), MIL-88-Fe (88.58 mV dec−1), and B0.25-MIL-88-Fe (90.12 mV dec−1) as shown in Fig. 4(b). This accounts for the incorporation of Co reinforcing the kinetics of OER. In order to achieve more exact analysis of the influences of diverse ions and their concentrations on the performance of OER, a sequence of samples with varying Fe:Co ratios and B doping extents were synthesized. The overpotentials of MIL-88-Fe6Co1 and MIL-88-Fe2Co1 are 1.75 and 1.63 V, respectively (Fig. S6). The reaction exhibits higher activity when the Fe:Co ratio is 4:1, which can be attributed to its kinetic supremacy that is evidenced by the presence of the lowest Tafel value. The electron transfer capability between Fe and Co is restricted because of low content of Co, whereas the MIL-88-Fe2Co1 sample tends to agglomerate ( Fig. S1c) that impacts the mass transfer process due to more addition of Co. Additionally, different B doping levels only generate minor variations in the corresponding overpotential, revealing the accession of diverse B contents does not impact OER performance ( Fig. S7). The double-layer capacitances (C dl) values which are directly proportional to the electrochemically active surface areas (ECSA) can be obtained by conducting cyclic voltammetry tests at varying scan rates (Fig. S8 ), which responds to the number of active sites on the electrode surface. As shown in Fig. 4(c), the MIL-88-Fe4Co1 catalyst exhibits the highest C dl value of 1.3 mF cm−2, manifesting its deeper potential to afford more venues for OER. The electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) data exhibited in Fig. 4(d) illustrates the charge transfer ability of a series of samples. Detailed values for various electrochemical parameters can be obtained through fitting the Nyquist plots to an equivalent circuit (Table S5). The lowest resistance value R s (0.15 Ω) is noticed in the MIL-88-Fe4Co1 sample, demonstrating its superior charge transfer capability and optimal kinetics during the OER. This conclusion is consistent with the results obtained from the Tafel analysis. A critical factor for catalysts is stability, which indicates whether phenomena such as decomposition, corrosion, and deactivation occur to evaluate its practicability. Chronoamperometric experiments were carried out at a constant potential of 1.56 V for MIL-88-Fe4Co1 (Fig. S9). Over a 36-hour period, the decrease in current density is negligible, and the fluctuations in the curve were attributed to the accumulation of evolved oxygen on the catalyst surface. Additionally, compared to the pre-test measurements, the polarization curve after the cyclic testing shows that the overpotential only increased by 9 mV at current density of 10 mA cm−2. These results clearly manifest that the doping of Co not only facilitates electron transfer but also enhances the stability of MIL-88-Fe. At last, the significance of Co doping for MIL-88-Fe4Co1 has been validated in Fig. 4(e), placing it among the relatively splendid performers of recently reported OER catalysts with similar structures [52,54–68]. 3.3 Electrochemical performance toward NRR LSV tests were carried out in H-cell (Fig. S10) saturated with Ar or N2 to define the optimal NRR test range for B0.25-MIL-88-Fe4Co1 (Fig. 5 a) [69]. The NH3 content was measured by indophenol blue method (Fig. S11) and the influence of electrolyte pH on the NRR property was investigated. As shown in Fig. S12, there is a remarkable trend where the yields of NH3 and faraday efficiency (FE) gradually rise as the pH descends. This is connected with the concentration of H+ that higher concentration of H+ is avail for the hydrogenation process in the NRR [48]. For the sake of mitigating the potential inaccuracies of a single detection method, the NH3 content was quantified using the Nessler method (Fig. S13). B0.25-MIL-88-Fe4Co1 manifested nearly identical NH3 yield across the diverse detection methods (Fig. S14). The accuracy of the results was ensured based on three repeated experiments. The optimal yield of NH3 and FE for B0.25-MIL-88-Fe4Co1 are recorded being 127.27 μg h−1 mg−1 cat and 25.81%, respectively, occurring at a potential of −0.3 V. When larger potentials are applied, the competitive HER tends to occur more readily than NRR, leading to the reduction of NH3 yield and FE (Fig. 5b) [69]. The time-current density curve and the ultraviolet-visible (UV-Vis) absorption spectra corresponding to B0.25-MIL-88-Fe4Co1 are displayed in Fig. S15, which indicates that the catalyst maintains good stability under diverse potentials for NRR. In Fig. 5(c), it can be observed that the NH3 production of the B0.25-MIL-88-Fe4Co1 is higher than that of B0.25-MIL-88-Fe (69.68 μg h−1 mg−1 cat), MIL-88-Fe4Co1 (86.65 μg h−1 mg−1 cat), and MIL-88-Fe (54.48 μg h−1 mg−1 cat) and the similar trend is noted for FE as shown in Fig. 5(d). The superior performance of B0.25-MIL-88-Fe4Co1 contrasted with currently reported catalysts (Table S6) can be ascribed to three key factors. (I) The improvement of the hydrophilicity of the samples accelerates the hydrogenation step in NRR. (II) The defects generated by B doping increase the specific surface area, exposing more active sites. (III) The doping of Co causes a change for the electronic structure around Fe in the sample, which is in favor of the enhancement of the nitrogen adsorption. The NRR performance of samples doped with varying Co and B levels has shown in Figs. S16 and S17. Based on the SEM data, it appears feasible to verify the roots of the decreased NH3 yield of MIL-88-Fe2Co1. Superfluous cobalt reacts with H2BDC to form particles that cover the surface, which affects the activity of active sites. The structural stability of the B0.5-MIL-88-Fe4Co1 decreases when the addition of H3BO3 reaches 0.5 mol, which is certified by the weakest diffraction peak observable in the XRD. Inversely, the capacity of low addition of Co and B to modulate the electronic structure of the catalyst is limited. To validate the experimental exactitude, the comprehensive experimental protocol has been devised, as depicted in Fig. S18. All instruments and consumables necessitated for the experimental process, such as H-cell, gases, catalysts, and electrodes, underwent thorough cleaning to exclude nitrogen distraction. Prior to the introduction of N2 into the experimental setup, it sequentially passed through 0.1 M KOH and 0.05 M H2SO4 solutions to take the edge off the effects of NO x −. The contamination absence of NO2 − and NO3 − is substantiated by the lack of peaks in the UV-Vis absorption spectrum at wavelengths of 545 and 200–250 nm (Figs. S19 and Fig. S20). As illustrated in Fig. S21, under conditions of NRR tests at open-circuit potential, utilizing Ar as the reactant, a pure electrolyte solution, and blank glassy carbon (GC) electrode, the yield of NH3 approaches about 0, establishing that the nitrogen in NH3 originates solely from N2. The Watt-Chrisp method can inspect N2H4 entity, showing no fluctuations in absorbance within the wavelength range of 440–520 nm, which certifies that B0.25-MIL-88-Fe4Co1 is highly selective for the NRR (Figs. S22 and S23). The B0.25-MIL-88-Fe4Co1 demonstrated no current density attenuation during a stability experiment up to 12 h in Fig. 5(e). Throughout the five cycles, the NH3 yields and FE at the −0.3 V potential kept nearly unchanged for B0.25-MIL-88-Fe4Co1. These results collectively affirm the exceptional durability and NH3 production capability of B0.25-MIL-88-Fe4Co1. 3.4 Electrochemical performance of aqueous Zn-N2 battery Owing to the outstanding catalytic activity in OER and NRR, B0.25-MIL-88-Fe4Co1 has enormous possibilities as electrode material for rechargeable Zn-N2 batteries. In the H-shaped cell pool, the cathode where the catalyst material is located and the anode where the zinc plate is situated are separated by Nafion 117 membrane (Fig. S24). The catalyst material acts as the positive electrode constantly, undergoing the NRR reaction to produce NH3 in the discharge phase and the OER reaction to generate O2 during the charging process, as seen in Fig. 6 (a) [6]. Meanwhile, the effects of the electrolyte and loading of catalyst in Zn-N2 batteries are investigated. In acidic solutions, zinc plates are readily corroded into Zn2+, and the charging phase in Zn-N2 batteries is hampered by low OER performance [70]. Although alkaline solutions endorse mass transfer, lower H+ concentration can also diminish NH3 production [71]. Considering the above factors, 1 M KOH is selected as the electrolyte in which B0.25-MIL-88-Fe4Co1 exhibits good stability (Fig. S25a). For Fig. S25(b), the performance of catalyst loading of 10 mg is lower than that of 5 mg due to reduced utilization efficiency. By reason of the fact that B0.25-MIL-88-Fe4Co1 has extraordinary catalytic activity, the charging-discharging potential gap is smaller than that of B0.25-MIL-88-Fe, MIL-88-Fe4Co1, and MIL-88-Fe (Fig. S26). Beyond that, power density is the crucial metric for assessing Zn-N2 batteries. It can be seen from Fig. 6(b), B0.25-MIL-88-Fe4Co1 displays well power density of 8.30 mW cm−2, which is higher than B0.25-MIL-88-Fe (7.19 mW cm−2), MIL-88-Fe4Co1 (6.4 mW cm−2), and MIL-88-Fe (3.7 mW cm−2) and roughly identical to the previous reports in Table S7. Based on the tremendous potential of B0.25-MIL-88-Fe4Co1 in Zn-N2 batteries, long-cycle studies were conducted in 1 M KOH solutions configured with both tap water and ultra-pure water to assess its stability and utility. As shown in Fig. 6(c), the excellent durability of B0.25-MIL-88-Fe4Co1 can be observed by the almost negligible fluctuation in the potential window after undergoing 40 cycles. Additionally, this is further supported by the fact that the XRD, SEM, and XPS of B0.25-MIL-88-Fe4Co1 are unaltered before and after the circulation (Fig. S27). The reason for the increased charging-discharging potential gap of B0.25-MIL-88-Fe4Co1 in tap water is the presence of a significant amount of impurities and Cl−, which leads to the occurrence of the chlorine evolution reaction (CER) [70]. 3.5 Mechanism analysis To obtain a comprehensive and profound comprehending of the mechanism of doping improving catalytic performance, we conducted computational analysis on a series of synthesized materials. Fig. 7 (a) presents the projected density of states (PDOS) of four distinct samples. Compared with the original MIL-88-Fe, it can be observed that the band gaps of B0.25-MIL-88-Fe, MIL-88-Fe4Co1, and B0.25-MIL-88-Fe4Co1 gradually shrink. Among them, B0.25-MIL-88-Fe4Co1 has the smallest band gap value of 0.09 eV, exhibiting metallic characteristics. This phenomenon implies that there are abundant electrons capable of transitioning near the Fermi level, and thus B0.25-MIL-88-Fe4Co1 exhibits excellent electrical conductivity. In the NRR free energy path of Fig. 7(b), it can be observed that the rate-determining step (RDS) of the NRR catalyzed by MIL-88-Fe is the first hydrogenation process (*N2 to *NNH). However, it is noteworthy that after the introduction of cobalt and boron, the free energy value decreases from the original 1.41 to 0.63 eV. This manifests that B0.25-MIL-88-Fe4Co1 has more prospect in NRR in contrast to MIL-88-Fe. This aspect is attributed to the cobalt-boron doping inducing a rearrangement of electrons within the MOF, while the other factors are pertained to the increase of defects during the doping process that conduces to N2 adsorption. Fig. 7(c) illustrates the reaction midbody structure model for B0.25-MIL-88-Fe4Co1 abiding by the distal hydrogenation mechanism. The lack of the by-product (N2H4, Fig.S23) also corroborates the rationality of this mechanism. Converging the outcomes of calculations, it is evident that the dual-doping scheme modulates the charge permutation mode of MIL-88-Fe, strengthens the conductivity, and accelerates the constitution of the crux active intermediate *N2H. 4 Conclusions In summary, the cobalt-boron dual-doped metal-organic framework (MOF) materials are successfully acquired through secondary solvothermal method, which is also affirmed as an excellent positive electrode catalyst for Zn-N2 batteries. The shifts of peaks in XRD, the emergence of the BO2 − characteristic peak in FTIR spectra, and the variations in peak intensity in Raman spectra all provide conclusive evidences for the successful doping of heteroatoms. The alteration in the electronic structure of the catalyst and the strong coupling effects between Fe, Co, and B are mirrored in the XPS results. Density functional theory (DFT) and DOS calculations clarify the mechanisms underlying the enhancement of catalytic performance. The reduction in the distance between the d-band center of Fe and the Fermi level implies an increase in the conductivity of the MOF. The decline in the free energy of RDS signifies that cobalt-boron doping expedites the kinetics of the nitrogen reduction reaction. It is suggested by these findings that cobalt and boron co-doping is a viable approach to enhance catalytic performance. This research establishes a solid foundation for future investigations in the field of Zn-N2 battery technology and provides novel viewpoints for researchers in related fields. coredata.dc:description: Zn-N2 batteries, which are comprised of nitrogen reduction reaction (NRR) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER), represent an emerging technology for efficient ammonia production and simultaneous power generation. Nevertheless, the intrinsic limitations of NRR and OER currently preclude its advancement. In this paper, Co and B co-doped Lavoisier framework series materials (MIL) are synthesized. Rapid mass transfer is rendered feasible with B0.25-MIL-88-Fe4Co1 by the distinctive double cone microrods structure. The addition of soft acid metal node Co2+ and B with defective electronic structure modifies the electronic configuration of MIL-88-Fe. At the same time, doping causes defects in the metal-organic frameworks, expands effectively the pore size, and increases the specific surface area, thereby expediting the adsorption of N2 and the release of O2. The electrocatalysis results show that the dual-doping scheme increases the NH3 yield (127.27 μg−1 h−1 mg−1 cat) and Faraday efficiency (25.81%) while reducing the overpotential of OER (330 mV), achieving a power density of 8.30 mW cm−2 for Zn-N2 batteries. This discovery implements another avenue for the exploration of Zn-N2 battery materials and holds broader significance for advancing the field of energy storage and conversion.
